page.title: 11CHAROLAIS ON CRINGLE MOOR
page.content:
Approximately 900 feet above sea level on the Cleveland Hills there runs a herd of pure French Charolais cattle.They were imported in the nineteen sixties and are used for improving beef breeds.
Charolais are pure white or pale cream in colour and are a large hardy breed that will winter out of doors and suckle their own calves.
Heifers are kept to improve the herd, whilst bulls are sold to improve other herds. Some of the bulls are used for "crossing" with British breeds to produce fast-growing calves for beef which is lean tender and popular with the housewife.
